docs.lead_paragraph: IF my mother died of breast cancer at 55, what are my chances of getting the disease? My father and grandfather both had colon cancer, does that mean I should go for genetic testing? These are questions that Melanie McDermet, the new genetics counselor at Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, is trained to answer. Ms. McDermet is one of about 100 professionals throughout the country currently specializing in the field of cancer genetics.

headline.main: Specializing in the Genetics of Cancer

docs.abstract: Melanie McDermet, new genetics counselor at Central Suffolk Hospital, answers questions on what family history might tell about one's chances for developing cancer, especially breast cancer; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IF my mother died of breast cancer at 55, what are my chances of getting the disease? My father and grandfather both had colon cancer, does that mean I should go for genetic testing?    These are questions that Melanie McDermet, the new genetics...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's Practical Traveler column ''Finding Out About Vaccines'' (Nov. 24) omitted mention of rabies. Early in November in Nepal, while observing a funeral ceremony in Katmandu, an Australian woman in our party of trekkers was suddenly bitten by a monkey. The animal's behavior, quite unprovoked, was bizarre enough that rabies was strongly suspected and she began treatment a few hours later. Had the attack occurred in a more remote area, treatment, which should be administered within eight hours or so, might not have been so readily available, with potentially fatal results.
docs.abstract: Letter by Christine Ammer on Betsy Wade's Nov 24 Practical Traveler column on travel vaccines (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A PARENT of a toddler who is not speaking at all, or not speaking clearly, may wonder: Is there something wrong with my child? Sometimes it is just a matter of time before the child will be speaking normally. In other cases, speech therapy is needed. Particularly if the problem is more than just one of articulation, professionals in the field say early intervention is a benefit. What is a parent to do? Sit and wait or be what some might consider neurotic and run to the speech therapist before it is certain there is a problem? The answer, said Terry Schlanger of Briarcliff Manor, the mother of three children who needed speech therapy, is to be aware, to consult a pediatrician or other health professional -- especially if your child has had many ear infections -- and take action when needed.

headline.main: A Mother's Case for Early Speech Therapy

docs.abstract: Interview with Terry Schlanger on importance of seeking early therapy for children with speech problems; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Administration officials say President Clinton has made a significant decision about budget strategy for 1997: he will not propose any increase in costs for Medicare beneficiaries, but will try to cut back payments to hospitals, doctors and others who provide health care to the elderly. Congressional Republicans say they too are unlikely to seek any increase in premiums or other charges for beneficiaries because, in last year's elections, they were pummeled by Democrats for having supported such proposals.

headline.main: Clinton and G.O.P. Are Unlikely To seek Medicare Premium Rise

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration decides not to propose any increase in costs for Medicare beneficiaries, but will try to cut back payments to Medicare health providers; Congressional Republicans say they too are unlikely to seek any increase in premiums or other charges for beneficiaries (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BARTERED babies? It's not the headline-screaming scandal it sounds. For John and Shari Atwater of Hartford, who had no health insurance, it was the perfect solution. Mr. Atwater swapped the services of his auto body business for his wife's obstetrical care. ''Babies cost a lot of money,'' he explained. ''When it comes out of pocket, it hurts.'' The couple's second child, due in April, will also be a bartered baby, and the Atwaters hope they can barter the hospital bill as well.

headline.main: Trade You a Wedding for a Hair Transplant?

docs.abstract: Sixth annual Expo of Barter Business Unlimited in Hartford, Conn, brings together 1,600 of its members, a testament to the growth of bartering in Connecticut; Barter Business Unlimited negotiates price for goods and services members are willing to exchange, keeps track of their debits and credits and reports all transactions to IRS for tax purposes; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Attorney General has taken a ''crucial first step'' toward requiring Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey to turn over millions of dollars to a charitable trust before it merges with a private insurance company based in Indianapolis, the state's largest consumer group said yesterday. The group, New Jersey Citizen Action, said Blue Cross has as much as $1 billion in assets that accumulated as it received tax breaks and subsidies for being the state's insurer of last resort.
docs.abstract: New Jersey Citizen Action reports that State Atty Gen has taken 'crucial first step' toward requiring Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey to turn over millions of dollars to charitable trust before it merges with private insurance company based in Indianapolis (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)

docs.lead_paragraph: Florida lawmakers who take gifts in the form of food and drinks from lobbyists in 1997 had better report them. In Michigan, should parents divorce and neglect child support payments, their driver's licenses may be revoked. Across the country, thousands of ideas that made their way from committee to governor's desk became law yesterday.

headline.main: New '97 Laws On Drinking, And Driving And Divorce

docs.lead_paragraph: THE stock market was booming. Companies were fighting their way into fast-growing foreign markets. Technology was transforming many industries. A blue-chip panel of business leaders, economists and government officials hailed ''the dynamic equilibrium of recent years,'' and the ''organic balance of economic forces.'' Their report on the nation's economic outlook concluded: ''Our situation is fortunate, our momentum remarkable.''

headline.main: Those Vicious Business Cycles: Tamed but Not Quite Slain

docs.abstract: Sweeping changes may have better equipped economy to maintain its long-run equilibrium, diminishing severity of business cycles; most business economists see sustainable growth and low inflation ahead as economy enjoys long recovery; more moderate business cycle, which some argue results in lost growth and opportunity, does not necessarily spur progress in dealing with income inequality, other deep-rooted problems; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If Federal officials think that new rules curbing bonuses to doctors in health maintenance organizations as rewards for controlling costs will protect Medicare and Medicaid patients (front page, Dec. 25), they should think again. Left intact is the H.M.O.'s power to control doctors by keeping that part of the doctor's pay they withhold or by simply dismissing ''uneconomic'' doctors.

headline.kicker: Pataki Needs to Finish Battle on H.M.O. Issues

docs.abstract: Dr Coleman R Seskind letter disputes December 25 article on new rules curbing bonuses to doctors in health maintenance organizations (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    If Federal officials think that new rules curbing bonuses to doctors in health maintenance organizations as rewards for controlling costs will protect Medicare and Medicaid patients (front page, Dec. 25), they should think again....

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In her call for a new method to resolve disputes over experimental treatments (''One Man's Battle With Managed Care,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 28), Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross ignores several years of New York State legislative history.

headline.main: Pataki Needs to Finish Battle on H.M.O. Issues

docs.abstract: Letter from Assemblymen Alexander B Grannis and Richard N Gottfried disputes December 28 Op-Ed article by New York State Lieut Gov Betsy McCaughey on managed care; says she ignored several years of state legislative history in call for new method to resolve disputes over experimental treatments (M)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In her call for a new method to resolve disputes over experimental treatments (''One Man's Battle With Managed Care,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 28), Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross ignores several years of New York State legislative history.
